content:
Outside your habitat the sky is a cold, dark vacuum that expands endlessly overhead. There’s something about being stationary on a vast plain of silver-gray regolith that unsettles the older generation. They talk about ship life on the Arvad as being more insular and contained, and how there didn’t used to be a sense of outside like there is now.

But you love the outside. You have come of age in this thrilling new environment and can’t wait to be recruited to a crew to begin exploring the asteroid belt. As you leave behind adolescence and enter adulthood you are ready to take the first steps on your chosen path. 

Your general education completed, you must now choose which class to join so that your specialized education can begin, you can learn a trade, and earn a living.
prompt: Which class do you want to join?

linkedPaths.text: Miner: While on the surface it may appear that miners value the strength of their backs over their brains, like their quarry, the reality lies underneath: they are highly skilled and knowledgeable in their area of expertise.
Engineer: If there is a problem, an engineer will find an answer. Whether it is buildings, ships, or processes, engineers are thrilled to be the one to solve the puzzle.

Merchant: Predictions of the ebb and flow of goods and services are about more than numbers on a spreadsheet, they are about anticipating the needs and desires of humanity, something merchants strive to understand.
Scientist: Motivated by a desire to expand human knowledge, scientists have the capability to learn from the past, while keeping their gaze steadily on the future.
Pilot: Often restless, and always ready for adventure, pilots are happiest when they are flying. Their expertise gets them and their crew where they want to go quickly, safely, and efficiently.

paths.content: As you’ve grown, you’ve begun to have a more mature appreciation of what it means to take your place in society. You find that some old friends’ ambitions do not quite align with yours, while some of your new acquaintances have the same motivations as you. You are becoming more confident in understanding your place in the universe.
paths.prompt: What drives you?

linkedPaths.text: Survival: You need to live. Your primary drive is the survival of yourself, the people you know, and the species.
Service: You need to fulfill your role. Your primary drive is to serve humanity for the greater good.
Glory: You need to excel. Your primary drive is to be the best at whatever you do.
Command: You need to be in control. Your primary drive is to lead others in what you know to be the right direction.

paths.content:
While it may not be the most glamorous of callings, you realize that mining will always be in high demand everywhere in the belt. It is the absolute foundation of the Adalian economy and helping break rock will never go out of style.

Plus, it’s the type of life that just appeals to you. Boots on the surface of an asteroid, finding out what lies beneath, exploring somewhere no human has ever been before - and the added bonus of getting paid well, if what you find is in high demand. What’s not to love?

You enroll in the remote learning sessions run by the Allen Mining Company. The introductory session is hosted by Harriet Auburn, former Chief Steward of the Arvad, and Scott Allen, descendant of the Allen mining oligarchs that sourced the raw materials that the great generational ships were built from, including the Arvad herself. 

"Future miners of Adalia, I’m glad to see so many of you here today," Auburn begins. "Deep space asteroid mining was an extremely niche field of study up until very recently, and no one knows it better than Scott, here." Auburn gestures to Scott Allen, his eyes sparkling under his bushy gray eyebrows as he continues with the introduction, "It is immensely gratifying to see it become so central to our growing civilization now, during what I foolishly thought would be my years of peaceful retirement. But these days, no miner is ever really done with their work, I suppose."

He pauses for a second, studying the video feeds on his screen.

"Oh, it’s not that bad!" he reassures the audience. "Once it is all set up properly, most of the mining process is fairly automated, honestly. It’s hard work for a little while, sure, but there’s also plenty of time to reflect on the great mysteries of life and the universe until the storage fills up or the trouble light comes on. You’ll all be part-time philosophers by the time you’re my age."

"Mmmhmm, part-time philosophers, for sure," Auburn agrees, with a small smile. "But first," she continues, coming back on topic, "there’s some more immediate and practical book learning to do. Setting up an excavator and turning it on may look easy at first glance, but knowing exactly where to set it up in the first place is an art and a science. By the time you graduate, you will know so much about reading the surface of an asteroid and working out what is going on below the outer layer that you will always be sought out for your skill."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of mining there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Surveyor: You will have increased core sampling speed while surveying an asteroid.
Recycler: You will have decreased loss when reprocessing materials.
Prospector: You will have increased viability gain per core sample.

paths.content: Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Miner of Adalia.
paths.prompt: You are ready to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

paths.content:
An independent adult now, you are a child of the asteroid belt living among the ship-born older generations as an equal. You have figured out who you are and how you fit into the universe during your adolescence. 

With the completion of your training, and certification, you are now ready to do your part in colonizing the belt. You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.

paths.prompt: You are ready to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

While it may not be the most glamorous of callings, you realize that mining will always be in high demand everywhere in the belt. It is the absolute foundation of the Adalian economy and helping break rock will never go out of style.

Plus, it’s the type of life that just appeals to you. Boots on the surface of an asteroid, finding out what lies beneath, exploring somewhere no human has ever been before - and the added bonus of getting paid well, if what you find is in high demand. What’s not to love?

You enroll in the remote learning sessions run by the Allen Mining Company. The introductory session is hosted by Harriet Auburn, former Chief Steward of the Arvad, and Scott Allen, descendant of the Allen mining oligarchs that sourced the raw materials that the great generational ships were built from, including the Arvad herself. 

"Future miners of Adalia, I’m glad to see so many of you here today," Auburn begins. "Deep space asteroid mining was an extremely niche field of study up until very recently, and no one knows it better than Scott, here." Auburn gestures to Scott Allen, his eyes sparkling under his bushy gray eyebrows as he continues with the introduction, "It is immensely gratifying to see it become so central to our growing civilization now, during what I foolishly thought would be my years of peaceful retirement. But these days, no miner is ever really done with their work, I suppose."

He pauses for a second, studying the video feeds on his screen.

"Oh, it’s not that bad!" he reassures the audience. "Once it is all set up properly, most of the mining process is fairly automated, honestly. It’s hard work for a little while, sure, but there’s also plenty of time to reflect on the great mysteries of life and the universe until the storage fills up or the trouble light comes on. You’ll all be part-time philosophers by the time you’re my age."

"Mmmhmm, part-time philosophers, for sure," Auburn agrees, with a small smile. "But first," she continues, coming back on topic, "there’s some more immediate and practical book learning to do. Setting up an excavator and turning it on may look easy at first glance, but knowing exactly where to set it up in the first place is an art and a science. By the time you graduate, you will know so much about reading the surface of an asteroid and working out what is going on below the outer layer that you will always be sought out for your skill."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of mining there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Surveyor: You will have increased core sampling speed while surveying an asteroid.
Recycler: You will have decreased loss when reprocessing materials.
Prospector: You will have increased viability gain per core sample.

paths.content: Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Miner of Adalia.

Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.prompt: You are ready to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.

Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

With the completion of your training, and certification, you are now ready to do your part in colonizing the belt. You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

While it may not be the most glamorous of callings, you realize that mining will always be in high demand everywhere in the belt. It is the absolute foundation of the Adalian economy and helping break rock will never go out of style.

Plus, it’s the type of life that just appeals to you. Boots on the surface of an asteroid, finding out what lies beneath, exploring somewhere no human has ever been before - and the added bonus of getting paid well, if what you find is in high demand. What’s not to love?

You enroll in the remote learning sessions run by the Allen Mining Company. The introductory session is hosted by Harriet Auburn, former Chief Steward of the Arvad, and Scott Allen, descendant of the Allen mining oligarchs that sourced the raw materials that the great generational ships were built from, including the Arvad herself. 

"Future miners of Adalia, I’m glad to see so many of you here today," Auburn begins. "Deep space asteroid mining was an extremely niche field of study up until very recently, and no one knows it better than Scott, here." Auburn gestures to Scott Allen, his eyes sparkling under his bushy gray eyebrows as he continues with the introduction, "It is immensely gratifying to see it become so central to our growing civilization now, during what I foolishly thought would be my years of peaceful retirement. But these days, no miner is ever really done with their work, I suppose."

He pauses for a second, studying the video feeds on his screen.

"Oh, it’s not that bad!" he reassures the audience. "Once it is all set up properly, most of the mining process is fairly automated, honestly. It’s hard work for a little while, sure, but there’s also plenty of time to reflect on the great mysteries of life and the universe until the storage fills up or the trouble light comes on. You’ll all be part-time philosophers by the time you’re my age."

"Mmmhmm, part-time philosophers, for sure," Auburn agrees, with a small smile. "But first," she continues, coming back on topic, "there’s some more immediate and practical book learning to do. Setting up an excavator and turning it on may look easy at first glance, but knowing exactly where to set it up in the first place is an art and a science. By the time you graduate, you will know so much about reading the surface of an asteroid and working out what is going on below the outer layer that you will always be sought out for your skill."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of mining there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Surveyor: You will have increased core sampling speed while surveying an asteroid.
Recycler: You will have decreased loss when reprocessing materials.
Prospector: You will have increased viability gain per core sample.

paths.content: Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Miner of Adalia.

Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

With the completion of your training, and certification, you are now ready to do your part in colonizing the belt. You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Miner of Adalia.
paths.prompt: You are ready to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

With the completion of your training, and certification, you are now ready to do your part in colonizing the belt. You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

While it may not be the most glamorous of callings, you realize that mining will always be in high demand everywhere in the belt. It is the absolute foundation of the Adalian economy and helping break rock will never go out of style.

Plus, it’s the type of life that just appeals to you. Boots on the surface of an asteroid, finding out what lies beneath, exploring somewhere no human has ever been before - and the added bonus of getting paid well, if what you find is in high demand. What’s not to love?

You enroll in the remote learning sessions run by the Allen Mining Company. The introductory session is hosted by Harriet Auburn, former Chief Steward of the Arvad, and Scott Allen, descendant of the Allen mining oligarchs that sourced the raw materials that the great generational ships were built from, including the Arvad herself. 

"Future miners of Adalia, I’m glad to see so many of you here today," Auburn begins. "Deep space asteroid mining was an extremely niche field of study up until very recently, and no one knows it better than Scott, here." Auburn gestures to Scott Allen, his eyes sparkling under his bushy gray eyebrows as he continues with the introduction, "It is immensely gratifying to see it become so central to our growing civilization now, during what I foolishly thought would be my years of peaceful retirement. But these days, no miner is ever really done with their work, I suppose."

He pauses for a second, studying the video feeds on his screen.

"Oh, it’s not that bad!" he reassures the audience. "Once it is all set up properly, most of the mining process is fairly automated, honestly. It’s hard work for a little while, sure, but there’s also plenty of time to reflect on the great mysteries of life and the universe until the storage fills up or the trouble light comes on. You’ll all be part-time philosophers by the time you’re my age."

"Mmmhmm, part-time philosophers, for sure," Auburn agrees, with a small smile. "But first," she continues, coming back on topic, "there’s some more immediate and practical book learning to do. Setting up an excavator and turning it on may look easy at first glance, but knowing exactly where to set it up in the first place is an art and a science. By the time you graduate, you will know so much about reading the surface of an asteroid and working out what is going on below the outer layer that you will always be sought out for your skill."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of mining there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Surveyor: You will have increased core sampling speed while surveying an asteroid.
Recycler: You will have decreased loss when reprocessing materials.
Prospector: You will have increased viability gain per core sample.

paths.content: Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Miner of Adalia.
paths.prompt: You are ready to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

Astrogeology is difficult, surprisingly complex, and all together fascinating. The combination of theory and practice you received from your course prepared you for your final project: a solo mining expedition where you had to find and bring back the most valuable cubic meter of material that you could secure within a strict time limit. Now, you just have to pass a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

As you’ve grown, you’ve begun to have a more mature appreciation of what it means to take your place in society. You find that some old friends’ ambitions do not quite align with yours, while some of your new acquaintances have the same motivations as you. You are becoming more confident in understanding your place in the universe.
paths.prompt: What drives you?

linkedPaths.text: Survival: You need to live. Your primary drive is the survival of yourself, the people you know, and the species.
Service: You need to fulfill your role. Your primary drive is to serve humanity for the greater good.
Glory: You need to excel. Your primary drive is to be the best at whatever you do.
Command: You need to be in control. Your primary drive is to lead others in what you know to be the right direction.

paths.content:
Throughout your life you have excelled at solving problems, especially those that are of a technical nature. You are confident in your choice to become an engineer, and while this career might not garner as much prestige as scientists, or as much money as merchants, everyone knows how indispensable an engineer is when something goes wrong. 

You enroll in the North Adalian Trade School, one of the engineering certification courses that have sprung up around the belt since the engineers of the Arvad made it possible to dismantle the great ship and create the first settlement on Adalia Prime. 

Eager to begin learning more about how everything around you works, and breaks, and can be repaired to work again, you signed up for the earliest orientation session available. The video begins abruptly and, without any introduction, the name of the last Head of Engineering of the Arvad appears at the bottom of the screen, with the man himself sitting front and center. Vikram Jay Stephenson has the look of a man who is perpetually busy, either in his work or in his mind. Even as he begins speaking, you can’t help notice that his attention seems divided between the encouraging talk meant for you, and the clutter of what appears to be a disassembled engine scattered around his workspace.

"You will be taught not just the basics of physics, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and such, but how to harness that knowledge to build, fix, improve everything that the average person uses everyday! Whether you choose to specialize in ships or building or refining or any one of the dozens of other possibilities, you will learn not just the what but the how. Being an engineer is about more than just testing hypotheses, it is about learning how to think so that you can solve any problem that comes your way." The subtle jab at the scientists’ academy does not go unnoticed by your new classmates and elicits a few quiet smirks around you.

Stephenson goes on, "Remember, there is a beauty in precision, in efficiency, in not only making a cold, hard chunk of metal come to life and do what you want it to, but to do it well." He makes a vague gesture toward the plant sitting behind him. The four broad leaves, two stick-like stems, and ghostly pale aerial roots give it an alien appearance, although, you suppose, all plants are technically alien to Adalia. You can see that while the orchid only has one open bloom at the moment, many more will soon follow.  "Strive for excellence, don’t compromise on quality, and your reputation as a great engineer, and a vital part of any crew, will grow."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of engineering there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Refiner: You will have increased refining yield while refining raw mined materials.
Mechanic: You will have decreased cost for ship repair.
Builder: You will have decreased assembly waste.

paths.content: Your school does an excellent job preparing you for the life of an engineer. After the initial foundation you gained in the classroom, you were sent out into the field to learn through hands-on experience. You completed your speciality-specific final project and now just have to pass the final certification exam, which covers a little bit of everything that you should have learned, so that you could always be useful if a ship breaks, if the process in a refinery needs to be tweaked, if a new building needs to be constructed or if any other problem comes your way.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, an Engineer of Adalia.

paths.prompt: It is now your turn to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

Your school does an excellent job preparing you for the life of an engineer. After the initial foundation you gained in the classroom, you were sent out into the field to learn through hands-on experience. You completed your speciality-specific final project and now just have to pass the final certification exam, which covers a little bit of everything that you should have learned, so that you could always be useful if a ship breaks, if the process in a refinery needs to be tweaked, if a new building needs to be constructed or if any other problem comes your way.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, an Engineer of Adalia.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

Throughout your life you have excelled at solving problems, especially those that are of a technical nature. You are confident in your choice to become an engineer, and while this career might not garner as much prestige as scientists, or as much money as merchants, everyone knows how indispensable an engineer is when something goes wrong. 

You enroll in the North Adalian Trade School, one of the engineering certification courses that have sprung up around the belt since the engineers of the Arvad made it possible to dismantle the great ship and create the first settlement on Adalia Prime. 

Eager to begin learning more about how everything around you works, and breaks, and can be repaired to work again, you signed up for the earliest orientation session available. The video begins abruptly and, without any introduction, the name of the last Head of Engineering of the Arvad appears at the bottom of the screen, with the man himself sitting front and center. Vikram Jay Stephenson has the look of a man who is perpetually busy, either in his work or in his mind. Even as he begins speaking, you can’t help notice that his attention seems divided between the encouraging talk meant for you, and the clutter of what appears to be a disassembled engine scattered around his workspace.

"You will be taught not just the basics of physics, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and such, but how to harness that knowledge to build, fix, improve everything that the average person uses everyday! Whether you choose to specialize in ships or building or refining or any one of the dozens of other possibilities, you will learn not just the what but the how. Being an engineer is about more than just testing hypotheses, it is about learning how to think so that you can solve any problem that comes your way." The subtle jab at the scientists’ academy does not go unnoticed by your new classmates and elicits a few quiet smirks around you.

Stephenson goes on, "Remember, there is a beauty in precision, in efficiency, in not only making a cold, hard chunk of metal come to life and do what you want it to, but to do it well." He makes a vague gesture toward the plant sitting behind him. The four broad leaves, two stick-like stems, and ghostly pale aerial roots give it an alien appearance, although, you suppose, all plants are technically alien to Adalia. You can see that while the orchid only has one open bloom at the moment, many more will soon follow.  "Strive for excellence, don’t compromise on quality, and your reputation as a great engineer, and a vital part of any crew, will grow."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of engineering there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Refiner: You will have increased refining yield while refining raw mined materials.
Mechanic: You will have decreased cost for ship repair.
Builder: You will have decreased assembly waste.

Your school does an excellent job preparing you for the life of an engineer. After the initial foundation you gained in the classroom, you were sent out into the field to learn through hands-on experience. You completed your speciality-specific final project and now just have to pass the final certification exam, which covers a little bit of everything that you should have learned, so that you could always be useful if a ship breaks, if the process in a refinery needs to be tweaked, if a new building needs to be constructed or if any other problem comes your way.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

Your school does an excellent job preparing you for the life of an engineer. After the initial foundation you gained in the classroom, you were sent out into the field to learn through hands-on experience. You completed your speciality-specific final project and now just have to pass the final certification exam, which covers a little bit of everything that you should have learned, so that you could always be useful if a ship breaks, if the process in a refinery needs to be tweaked, if a new building needs to be constructed or if any other problem comes your way.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

While you are standing on the shoulders of prior generations, you can’t help but think that there may be a better way of doing things. If only you can convince others to listen to your ideas…

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

Throughout your life you have excelled at solving problems, especially those that are of a technical nature. You are confident in your choice to become an engineer, and while this career might not garner as much prestige as scientists, or as much money as merchants, everyone knows how indispensable an engineer is when something goes wrong. 

You enroll in the North Adalian Trade School, one of the engineering certification courses that have sprung up around the belt since the engineers of the Arvad made it possible to dismantle the great ship and create the first settlement on Adalia Prime. 

Eager to begin learning more about how everything around you works, and breaks, and can be repaired to work again, you signed up for the earliest orientation session available. The video begins abruptly and, without any introduction, the name of the last Head of Engineering of the Arvad appears at the bottom of the screen, with the man himself sitting front and center. Vikram Jay Stephenson has the look of a man who is perpetually busy, either in his work or in his mind. Even as he begins speaking, you can’t help notice that his attention seems divided between the encouraging talk meant for you, and the clutter of what appears to be a disassembled engine scattered around his workspace.

"You will be taught not just the basics of physics, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and such, but how to harness that knowledge to build, fix, improve everything that the average person uses everyday! Whether you choose to specialize in ships or building or refining or any one of the dozens of other possibilities, you will learn not just the what but the how. Being an engineer is about more than just testing hypotheses, it is about learning how to think so that you can solve any problem that comes your way." The subtle jab at the scientists’ academy does not go unnoticed by your new classmates and elicits a few quiet smirks around you.

Stephenson goes on, "Remember, there is a beauty in precision, in efficiency, in not only making a cold, hard chunk of metal come to life and do what you want it to, but to do it well." He makes a vague gesture toward the plant sitting behind him. The four broad leaves, two stick-like stems, and ghostly pale aerial roots give it an alien appearance, although, you suppose, all plants are technically alien to Adalia. You can see that while the orchid only has one open bloom at the moment, many more will soon follow.  "Strive for excellence, don’t compromise on quality, and your reputation as a great engineer, and a vital part of any crew, will grow."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of engineering there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Refiner: You will have increased refining yield while refining raw mined materials.
Mechanic: You will have decreased cost for ship repair.
Builder: You will have decreased assembly waste.

paths.content: Your school does an excellent job preparing you for the life of an engineer. After the initial foundation you gained in the classroom, you were sent out into the field to learn through hands-on experience. You completed your speciality-specific final project and now just have to pass the final certification exam, which covers a little bit of everything that you should have learned, so that you could always be useful if a ship breaks, if the process in a refinery needs to be tweaked, if a new building needs to be constructed or if any other problem comes your way.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, an Engineer of Adalia.
paths.prompt: It is now your turn to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

Your school does an excellent job preparing you for the life of an engineer. After the initial foundation you gained in the classroom, you were sent out into the field to learn through hands-on experience. You completed your speciality-specific final project and now just have to pass the final certification exam, which covers a little bit of everything that you should have learned, so that you could always be useful if a ship breaks, if the process in a refinery needs to be tweaked, if a new building needs to be constructed or if any other problem comes your way.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

Throughout your life you have excelled at solving problems, especially those that are of a technical nature. You are confident in your choice to become an engineer, and while this career might not garner as much prestige as scientists, or as much money as merchants, everyone knows how indispensable an engineer is when something goes wrong. 

You enroll in the North Adalian Trade School, one of the engineering certification courses that have sprung up around the belt since the engineers of the Arvad made it possible to dismantle the great ship and create the first settlement on Adalia Prime. 

Eager to begin learning more about how everything around you works, and breaks, and can be repaired to work again, you signed up for the earliest orientation session available. The video begins abruptly and, without any introduction, the name of the last Head of Engineering of the Arvad appears at the bottom of the screen, with the man himself sitting front and center. Vikram Jay Stephenson has the look of a man who is perpetually busy, either in his work or in his mind. Even as he begins speaking, you can’t help notice that his attention seems divided between the encouraging talk meant for you, and the clutter of what appears to be a disassembled engine scattered around his workspace.

"You will be taught not just the basics of physics, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and such, but how to harness that knowledge to build, fix, improve everything that the average person uses everyday! Whether you choose to specialize in ships or building or refining or any one of the dozens of other possibilities, you will learn not just the what but the how. Being an engineer is about more than just testing hypotheses, it is about learning how to think so that you can solve any problem that comes your way." The subtle jab at the scientists’ academy does not go unnoticed by your new classmates and elicits a few quiet smirks around you.

Stephenson goes on, "Remember, there is a beauty in precision, in efficiency, in not only making a cold, hard chunk of metal come to life and do what you want it to, but to do it well." He makes a vague gesture toward the plant sitting behind him. The four broad leaves, two stick-like stems, and ghostly pale aerial roots give it an alien appearance, although, you suppose, all plants are technically alien to Adalia. You can see that while the orchid only has one open bloom at the moment, many more will soon follow.  "Strive for excellence, don’t compromise on quality, and your reputation as a great engineer, and a vital part of any crew, will grow."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of engineering there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Refiner: You will have increased refining yield while refining raw mined materials.
Mechanic: You will have decreased cost for ship repair.
Builder: You will have decreased assembly waste.

paths.content: Your school does an excellent job preparing you for the life of an engineer. After the initial foundation you gained in the classroom, you were sent out into the field to learn through hands-on experience. You completed your speciality-specific final project and now just have to pass the final certification exam, which covers a little bit of everything that you should have learned, so that you could always be useful if a ship breaks, if the process in a refinery needs to be tweaked, if a new building needs to be constructed or if any other problem comes your way.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, an Engineer of Adalia.

As you’ve grown, you’ve begun to have a more mature appreciation of what it means to take your place in society. You find that some old friends’ ambitions do not quite align with yours, while some of your new acquaintances have the same motivations as you. You are becoming more confident in understanding your place in the universe.
paths.prompt: What drives you?

linkedPaths.text: Survival: You need to live. Your primary drive is the survival of yourself, the people you know, and the species.
Service: You need to fulfill your role. Your primary drive is to serve humanity for the greater good.
Glory: You need to excel. Your primary drive is to be the best at whatever you do.
Command: You need to be in control. Your primary drive is to lead others in what you know to be the right direction.

paths.content:
The idea of going into business for yourself has always been fascinating to you so, of course, you are drawn to the idea of being a merchant. Buying low, selling high, and putting the difference in your pocket sounds like a great way to make a living in the belt.

Although anyone can call themselves a merchant, you decide to receive academic training in the fundamentals from an accredited school, the Merchants of Venus, who advertise their training with the tongue-in-cheek tagline: "Let us be your morning star, your evening star, your guiding light in the darkest corners of the Adalian marketplace."

The first day of your course starts with a remote lecture hosted by Mason Quince, who is not an academic but a real working merchant operating in the Outer Rim, and former Entertainment Director of the Arvad. He introduces himself briefly before starting on the main topic of his lecture.

"I do these guest lectures for two key reasons," he begins, "because I want to illustrate why knowing the fundamentals is key to being an effective merchant, and because the school pays me handsomely for my time." He smiles slyly at this, then continues.

"Everyone knows the old ‘buy low, sell high’ truism, and too many aspiring merchants think that’s all there is to it. And, sure, that’s part of it. You see that widgets are 10 SWAY here and 11 SWAY over there, and you think to yourself, ‘cool, that’s 1 SWAY profit per widget!’" But you forgot the fees to buy the widgets here, the propellant and fuel to get them there, the docking fees, and the market fees at your destination. Suddenly, it’s not worth moving those widgets, is it? In the real world there’s even more to it."

"You learn the fundamentals so that you can glean insights and make plans. Shipping widgets around chasing small price gradients is work for bulk cargo haulers with algorithms picking their manifests. Small independents like yourselves will get ground to dust going up against big operations like that. That’s a race-to-the-bottom game that you want to stay well away from.

"You want to be looking for what bulk hauler algorithms can’t see, and make moves that put you in good positions for the next trade and the trade after that. You need to know not just the numbers, but the humanity hiding behind those numbers. Understanding economics is impossible without first understanding people. That’s what you will learn here, and that’s what’s going to put you in a position to make the whole belt work better and more efficiently. And earn yourself some SWAY doing it, of course."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of commerce there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Hauler: You will have increased ship cargo capacity while travelling.
Mogul: You will have increased market volume capacity.
Logistician: You will have reduced surface transport fuel costs.

paths.content: During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Merchant of Adalia.
