During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Merchant of Adalia.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

The idea of going into business for yourself has always been fascinating to you so, of course, you are drawn to the idea of being a merchant. Buying low, selling high, and putting the difference in your pocket sounds like a great way to make a living in the belt.

Although anyone can call themselves a merchant, you decide to receive academic training in the fundamentals from an accredited school, the Merchants of Venus, who advertise their training with the tongue-in-cheek tagline: "Let us be your morning star, your evening star, your guiding light in the darkest corners of the Adalian marketplace."

The first day of your course starts with a remote lecture hosted by Mason Quince, who is not an academic but a real working merchant operating in the Outer Rim, and former Entertainment Director of the Arvad. He introduces himself briefly before starting on the main topic of his lecture.

"I do these guest lectures for two key reasons," he begins, "because I want to illustrate why knowing the fundamentals is key to being an effective merchant, and because the school pays me handsomely for my time." He smiles slyly at this, then continues.

"Everyone knows the old ‘buy low, sell high’ truism, and too many aspiring merchants think that’s all there is to it. And, sure, that’s part of it. You see that widgets are 10 SWAY here and 11 SWAY over there, and you think to yourself, ‘cool, that’s 1 SWAY profit per widget!’" But you forgot the fees to buy the widgets here, the propellant and fuel to get them there, the docking fees, and the market fees at your destination. Suddenly, it’s not worth moving those widgets, is it? In the real world there’s even more to it."

"You learn the fundamentals so that you can glean insights and make plans. Shipping widgets around chasing small price gradients is work for bulk cargo haulers with algorithms picking their manifests. Small independents like yourselves will get ground to dust going up against big operations like that. That’s a race-to-the-bottom game that you want to stay well away from.

"You want to be looking for what bulk hauler algorithms can’t see, and make moves that put you in good positions for the next trade and the trade after that. You need to know not just the numbers, but the humanity hiding behind those numbers. Understanding economics is impossible without first understanding people. That’s what you will learn here, and that’s what’s going to put you in a position to make the whole belt work better and more efficiently. And earn yourself some SWAY doing it, of course."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of commerce there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Hauler: You will have increased ship cargo capacity while travelling.
Mogul: You will have increased market volume capacity.
Logistician: You will have reduced surface transport fuel costs.

paths.content: During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Merchant of Adalia.

During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Merchant of Adalia.
paths.prompt: It is now your turn to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

The idea of going into business for yourself has always been fascinating to you so, of course, you are drawn to the idea of being a merchant. Buying low, selling high, and putting the difference in your pocket sounds like a great way to make a living in the belt.

Although anyone can call themselves a merchant, you decide to receive academic training in the fundamentals from an accredited school, the Merchants of Venus, who advertise their training with the tongue-in-cheek tagline: "Let us be your morning star, your evening star, your guiding light in the darkest corners of the Adalian marketplace."

The first day of your course starts with a remote lecture hosted by Mason Quince, who is not an academic but a real working merchant operating in the Outer Rim, and former Entertainment Director of the Arvad. He introduces himself briefly before starting on the main topic of his lecture.

"I do these guest lectures for two key reasons," he begins, "because I want to illustrate why knowing the fundamentals is key to being an effective merchant, and because the school pays me handsomely for my time." He smiles slyly at this, then continues.

"Everyone knows the old ‘buy low, sell high’ truism, and too many aspiring merchants think that’s all there is to it. And, sure, that’s part of it. You see that widgets are 10 SWAY here and 11 SWAY over there, and you think to yourself, ‘cool, that’s 1 SWAY profit per widget!’" But you forgot the fees to buy the widgets here, the propellant and fuel to get them there, the docking fees, and the market fees at your destination. Suddenly, it’s not worth moving those widgets, is it? In the real world there’s even more to it."

"You learn the fundamentals so that you can glean insights and make plans. Shipping widgets around chasing small price gradients is work for bulk cargo haulers with algorithms picking their manifests. Small independents like yourselves will get ground to dust going up against big operations like that. That’s a race-to-the-bottom game that you want to stay well away from.

"You want to be looking for what bulk hauler algorithms can’t see, and make moves that put you in good positions for the next trade and the trade after that. You need to know not just the numbers, but the humanity hiding behind those numbers. Understanding economics is impossible without first understanding people. That’s what you will learn here, and that’s what’s going to put you in a position to make the whole belt work better and more efficiently. And earn yourself some SWAY doing it, of course."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of commerce there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Hauler: You will have increased ship cargo capacity while travelling.
Mogul: You will have increased market volume capacity.
Logistician: You will have reduced surface transport fuel costs.

During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Merchant of Adalia.

During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Merchant of Adalia.

The idea of going into business for yourself has always been fascinating to you so, of course, you are drawn to the idea of being a merchant. Buying low, selling high, and putting the difference in your pocket sounds like a great way to make a living in the belt.

Although anyone can call themselves a merchant, you decide to receive academic training in the fundamentals from an accredited school, the Merchants of Venus, who advertise their training with the tongue-in-cheek tagline: "Let us be your morning star, your evening star, your guiding light in the darkest corners of the Adalian marketplace."

The first day of your course starts with a remote lecture hosted by Mason Quince, who is not an academic but a real working merchant operating in the Outer Rim, and former Entertainment Director of the Arvad. He introduces himself briefly before starting on the main topic of his lecture.

"I do these guest lectures for two key reasons," he begins, "because I want to illustrate why knowing the fundamentals is key to being an effective merchant, and because the school pays me handsomely for my time." He smiles slyly at this, then continues.

"Everyone knows the old ‘buy low, sell high’ truism, and too many aspiring merchants think that’s all there is to it. And, sure, that’s part of it. You see that widgets are 10 SWAY here and 11 SWAY over there, and you think to yourself, ‘cool, that’s 1 SWAY profit per widget!’" But you forgot the fees to buy the widgets here, the propellant and fuel to get them there, the docking fees, and the market fees at your destination. Suddenly, it’s not worth moving those widgets, is it? In the real world there’s even more to it."

"You learn the fundamentals so that you can glean insights and make plans. Shipping widgets around chasing small price gradients is work for bulk cargo haulers with algorithms picking their manifests. Small independents like yourselves will get ground to dust going up against big operations like that. That’s a race-to-the-bottom game that you want to stay well away from.

"You want to be looking for what bulk hauler algorithms can’t see, and make moves that put you in good positions for the next trade and the trade after that. You need to know not just the numbers, but the humanity hiding behind those numbers. Understanding economics is impossible without first understanding people. That’s what you will learn here, and that’s what’s going to put you in a position to make the whole belt work better and more efficiently. And earn yourself some SWAY doing it, of course."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of commerce there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Hauler: You will have increased ship cargo capacity while travelling.
Mogul: You will have increased market volume capacity.
Logistician: You will have reduced surface transport fuel costs.

paths.content: During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Merchant of Adalia.
paths.prompt: It is now your turn to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

During your training it seems that there are as many theories about the workings of the Adalian economy as there are merchants. Nevertheless, you learn that most of your professors are pragmatic and if you can show your reasoning behind an argument, your answer is likely to be accepted as plausible, even if it does not encompass their favorite approach. You managed to defend your final thesis to a panel of prominent merchants, and now you just need to complete the final written exam in order to graduate.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

As you’ve grown, you’ve begun to have a more mature appreciation of what it means to take your place in society. You find that some old friends’ ambitions do not quite align with yours, while some of your new acquaintances have the same motivations as you. You are becoming more confident in understanding your place in the universe.
paths.prompt: What drives you?

linkedPaths.text: Survival: You need to live. Your primary drive is the survival of yourself, the people you know, and the species.
Service: You need to fulfill your role. Your primary drive is to serve humanity for the greater good.
Glory: You need to excel. Your primary drive is to be the best at whatever you do.
Command: You need to be in control. Your primary drive is to lead others in what you know to be the right direction.

paths.content:
You have always been interested in not just the "what" but the "how" and "why" of the universe. While you know that some Adalians don’t understand the appeal of being a scientist, as it is seldom considered to be one of the most lucrative fields, you just can’t imagine a life where you don’t get the opportunity to investigate, invent, learn, and move humanity forward.

After passing the tricky entrance examination, you enroll in The Academy for the Study and Promotion of Sciences for Humanity (or The Academy, as it is affectionately referred to by its attendees). The Academy not only certifies scientists, but also offers further advanced certifications which would enable you to one day become a medical doctor or doctor of philosophy. It is known for its exacting standards and, consequently, its high drop-out rate.

With a bit of trepidation you meet the few other prospective scientists at one of the student labs in your habitat to view the orientation video. Dr. Susan Blackwell, the last Chief Medical Officer of the Arvad, appears on the screen. She emanates the kind of calm confidence that comes from years of careful study of one’s chosen field, and her friendly smile immediately puts you at ease, reminding you of your first pediatrician, the one who alway had a silly joke to share at every appointment.

"Hello future scientists! I’m so excited to welcome you to The Academy! Not only will you receive an excellent education in the experimental sciences of biology, chemistry, and physics, but here you will supplement your education with courses in the social sciences, such as psychology, anthropology, and sociology. Because each of you must remember our goal here, we want to further our understanding of the universe, yes, but most of all we want to help each other survive. We want humanity to continue to thrive in our little pocket of the universe!"

Whatever anxiety you were feeling about beginning this course of study is pushed to the side by the excitement you feel at the prospect of learning something new. You are looking forward to using the knowledge that you gain to one day invent something that no one in Adalia has ever seen before.
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of science there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Dietitian: You will have decreased food consumption needs among your crew.
Scholar: You will have decreased time to next technology.
Experimenter: You will have decreased time to next invention.

paths.content: The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Scientist of Adalia.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.

While you are standing on the shoulders of prior generations, you can’t help but think that there may be a better way of doing things. If only you can convince others to listen to your ideas…

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

You have always been interested in not just the "what" but the "how" and "why" of the universe. While you know that some Adalians don’t understand the appeal of being a scientist, as it is seldom considered to be one of the most lucrative fields, you just can’t imagine a life where you don’t get the opportunity to investigate, invent, learn, and move humanity forward.

After passing the tricky entrance examination, you enroll in The Academy for the Study and Promotion of Sciences for Humanity (or The Academy, as it is affectionately referred to by its attendees). The Academy not only certifies scientists, but also offers further advanced certifications which would enable you to one day become a medical doctor or doctor of philosophy. It is known for its exacting standards and, consequently, its high drop-out rate.

With a bit of trepidation you meet the few other prospective scientists at one of the student labs in your habitat to view the orientation video. Dr. Susan Blackwell, the last Chief Medical Officer of the Arvad, appears on the screen. She emanates the kind of calm confidence that comes from years of careful study of one’s chosen field, and her friendly smile immediately puts you at ease, reminding you of your first pediatrician, the one who alway had a silly joke to share at every appointment.

"Hello future scientists! I’m so excited to welcome you to The Academy! Not only will you receive an excellent education in the experimental sciences of biology, chemistry, and physics, but here you will supplement your education with courses in the social sciences, such as psychology, anthropology, and sociology. Because each of you must remember our goal here, we want to further our understanding of the universe, yes, but most of all we want to help each other survive. We want humanity to continue to thrive in our little pocket of the universe!"

Whatever anxiety you were feeling about beginning this course of study is pushed to the side by the excitement you feel at the prospect of learning something new. You are looking forward to using the knowledge that you gain to one day invent something that no one in Adalia has ever seen before.
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of science there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Dietitian: You will have decreased food consumption needs among your crew.
Scholar: You will have decreased time to next technology.
Experimenter: You will have decreased time to next invention.

paths.content: The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Scientist of Adalia.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

You have always been interested in not just the "what" but the "how" and "why" of the universe. While you know that some Adalians don’t understand the appeal of being a scientist, as it is seldom considered to be one of the most lucrative fields, you just can’t imagine a life where you don’t get the opportunity to investigate, invent, learn, and move humanity forward.

After passing the tricky entrance examination, you enroll in The Academy for the Study and Promotion of Sciences for Humanity (or The Academy, as it is affectionately referred to by its attendees). The Academy not only certifies scientists, but also offers further advanced certifications which would enable you to one day become a medical doctor or doctor of philosophy. It is known for its exacting standards and, consequently, its high drop-out rate.

With a bit of trepidation you meet the few other prospective scientists at one of the student labs in your habitat to view the orientation video. Dr. Susan Blackwell, the last Chief Medical Officer of the Arvad, appears on the screen. She emanates the kind of calm confidence that comes from years of careful study of one’s chosen field, and her friendly smile immediately puts you at ease, reminding you of your first pediatrician, the one who alway had a silly joke to share at every appointment.

"Hello future scientists! I’m so excited to welcome you to The Academy! Not only will you receive an excellent education in the experimental sciences of biology, chemistry, and physics, but here you will supplement your education with courses in the social sciences, such as psychology, anthropology, and sociology. Because each of you must remember our goal here, we want to further our understanding of the universe, yes, but most of all we want to help each other survive. We want humanity to continue to thrive in our little pocket of the universe!"

Whatever anxiety you were feeling about beginning this course of study is pushed to the side by the excitement you feel at the prospect of learning something new. You are looking forward to using the knowledge that you gain to one day invent something that no one in Adalia has ever seen before.
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of science there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Dietitian: You will have decreased food consumption needs among your crew.
Scholar: You will have decreased time to next technology.
Experimenter: You will have decreased time to next invention.

paths.content: The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Scientist of Adalia.

Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Scientist of Adalia.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

You have always been interested in not just the "what" but the "how" and "why" of the universe. While you know that some Adalians don’t understand the appeal of being a scientist, as it is seldom considered to be one of the most lucrative fields, you just can’t imagine a life where you don’t get the opportunity to investigate, invent, learn, and move humanity forward.

After passing the tricky entrance examination, you enroll in The Academy for the Study and Promotion of Sciences for Humanity (or The Academy, as it is affectionately referred to by its attendees). The Academy not only certifies scientists, but also offers further advanced certifications which would enable you to one day become a medical doctor or doctor of philosophy. It is known for its exacting standards and, consequently, its high drop-out rate.

With a bit of trepidation you meet the few other prospective scientists at one of the student labs in your habitat to view the orientation video. Dr. Susan Blackwell, the last Chief Medical Officer of the Arvad, appears on the screen. She emanates the kind of calm confidence that comes from years of careful study of one’s chosen field, and her friendly smile immediately puts you at ease, reminding you of your first pediatrician, the one who alway had a silly joke to share at every appointment.

"Hello future scientists! I’m so excited to welcome you to The Academy! Not only will you receive an excellent education in the experimental sciences of biology, chemistry, and physics, but here you will supplement your education with courses in the social sciences, such as psychology, anthropology, and sociology. Because each of you must remember our goal here, we want to further our understanding of the universe, yes, but most of all we want to help each other survive. We want humanity to continue to thrive in our little pocket of the universe!"

Whatever anxiety you were feeling about beginning this course of study is pushed to the side by the excitement you feel at the prospect of learning something new. You are looking forward to using the knowledge that you gain to one day invent something that no one in Adalia has ever seen before.
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of science there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Dietitian: You will have decreased food consumption needs among your crew.
Scholar: You will have decreased time to next technology.
Experimenter: You will have decreased time to next invention.

The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

The coursework at The Academy certainly lives up to its reputation: it is rigorous, challenging, and time consuming. You have barely had any time to keep up with your family or old friends, let alone to think of what you will do or where you will go once you graduate. You have now successfully completed your oral defense of your final speciality-specific project and, with graduation on the horizon, you have one last hurdle to clear: a final written exam.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

As you’ve grown, you’ve begun to have a more mature appreciation of what it means to take your place in society. You find that some old friends’ ambitions do not quite align with yours, while some of your new acquaintances have the same motivations as you. You are becoming more confident in understanding your place in the universe.
paths.prompt: What drives you?

linkedPaths.text: Survival: You need to live. Your primary drive is the survival of yourself, the people you know, and the species.
Service: You need to fulfill your role. Your primary drive is to serve humanity for the greater good.
Glory: You need to excel. Your primary drive is to be the best at whatever you do.
Command: You need to be in control. Your primary drive is to lead others in what you know to be the right direction.

paths.content:
The endless void of space calls to you. You dream of one day taking the helm of an Adalian ship, and exploring the entirety of Adalia. 

You enroll in Flight Academy and on the first day of your training, you and all the other aspiring pilots log into the remote learning session hosted from Adalia Prime’s education center. 

The video feed shows an older woman with a pilot’s mask and the bald head favored by lifelong pilots - like mohawks and topknots, it keeps any hair away from the large radio headsets clasped over their ears while flying.

"Good morning, class," she begins once everyone is logged in and settled. "I’m Flight Instructor Murcheson, and I have the distinction of being one of the longest serving pilots in all of Adalia, since I was a Specialist running EVA flights over the outer hull of the Arvad, back when the old girl still flew."

A small whispered comment comes from someone’s live mic, but abruptly cuts off once whoever it is notices the microphone icon on their console.

"Yes, yes," Murcheson says, pausing briefly to address this. "That’s not the only distinction I have from back in the old days, I know. Anyone who is more interested in old court cases than flying should consider transferring to another program. I’m here to train pilots."

The session attendees are silent.

"Good," Murcheson continues. "Speaking of ancient history, back then we had almost no EVA techs, and none of them would even really pass as a pilot today. Once we knew we would be settling a whole asteroid belt, we started training shuttle pilots as quickly as we could, and even then it wasn’t enough to keep up with all the flights we needed, bringing a whole starship down to the surface in pieces." 

She frowns slightly.

"We still struggle to turn out enough pilots to keep our ever expanding fleets moving about in the belt. We are just about there now, where every crew that wants a pilot can get one.

"Pilots," she says, "will always be in high demand. You will always have a job to do and a destination to head toward…once you graduate."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of flight there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Navigator: You will have increased ship fuel efficency while travelling.
Buster: You will have increased top ship acceleration.
Operator: You will have reduced rate of wear during ship operation.

paths.content: Flight Academy is tough, but you have a knack for it, and with a lot of practice in the simulator and just as much book learning, you complete your training. You pass your final flight test on a real shuttle and only have to pass the final written exam to become certified as a pilot.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Pilot of Adalia.
paths.prompt: It is now your turn to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

paths.content:
While you are standing on the shoulders of prior generations, you can’t help but think that there may be a better way of doing things. If only you can convince others to listen to your ideas…

Flight Academy is tough, but you have a knack for it, and with a lot of practice in the simulator and just as much book learning, you complete your training. You pass your final flight test on a real shuttle and only have to pass the final written exam to become certified as a pilot.

Flight Academy is tough, but you have a knack for it, and with a lot of practice in the simulator and just as much book learning, you complete your training. You pass your final flight test on a real shuttle and only have to pass the final written exam to become certified as a pilot.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

The endless void of space calls to you. You dream of one day taking the helm of an Adalian ship, and exploring the entirety of Adalia. 

You enroll in Flight Academy and on the first day of your training, you and all the other aspiring pilots log into the remote learning session hosted from Adalia Prime’s education center. 

The video feed shows an older woman with a pilot’s mask and the bald head favored by lifelong pilots - like mohawks and topknots, it keeps any hair away from the large radio headsets clasped over their ears while flying.

"Good morning, class," she begins once everyone is logged in and settled. "I’m Flight Instructor Murcheson, and I have the distinction of being one of the longest serving pilots in all of Adalia, since I was a Specialist running EVA flights over the outer hull of the Arvad, back when the old girl still flew."

A small whispered comment comes from someone’s live mic, but abruptly cuts off once whoever it is notices the microphone icon on their console.

"Yes, yes," Murcheson says, pausing briefly to address this. "That’s not the only distinction I have from back in the old days, I know. Anyone who is more interested in old court cases than flying should consider transferring to another program. I’m here to train pilots."

The session attendees are silent.

"Good," Murcheson continues. "Speaking of ancient history, back then we had almost no EVA techs, and none of them would even really pass as a pilot today. Once we knew we would be settling a whole asteroid belt, we started training shuttle pilots as quickly as we could, and even then it wasn’t enough to keep up with all the flights we needed, bringing a whole starship down to the surface in pieces." 

She frowns slightly.

"We still struggle to turn out enough pilots to keep our ever expanding fleets moving about in the belt. We are just about there now, where every crew that wants a pilot can get one.

"Pilots," she says, "will always be in high demand. You will always have a job to do and a destination to head toward…once you graduate."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of flight there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Navigator: You will have increased ship fuel efficency while travelling.
Buster: You will have increased top ship acceleration.
Operator: You will have reduced rate of wear during ship operation.

paths.content: Flight Academy is tough, but you have a knack for it, and with a lot of practice in the simulator and just as much book learning, you complete your training. You pass your final flight test on a real shuttle and only have to pass the final written exam to become certified as a pilot.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Pilot of Adalia.
paths.prompt: It is now your turn to find your place in Adalian society. As you leave your childhood behind, you feel:

linkedPaths.text: Adventurous: You are bold, brave, and intrepid. You recognize that in order to move humanity forward, it is sometimes necessary to take that giant leap for mankind.
Ambitious: You know what needs to be done, and you know that you are the one who can do it. You are driven to succeed, no matter the obstacles.

Arrogant: Hubris may have been the downfall of lesser people, but you are steadfastly confident in your own abilities. Let other people be led around by those stronger than themselves, you know what you are capable of.
Cautious: Let others leap before they look. You will stay with what you know works, until there is some proof that another course is safer.
Creative: You seek to bring new ideas to light. Your mind is constantly wandering to the question "what if..." You want to see if you can explain the "unexplainable".
Curious: You are excited to open your mind and learn something new. The universe is full of the undiscovered just waiting to be discovered.
Frantic: You are prone to anxiety and always forget your towel.
Independent: You are free-thinking and not prone to blindly following orders, unless there is a very good explanation behind those orders.
Irrational: You don't waste your time with logic, at least not the type that makes sense to anyone else. You have never had the dubious honor of being called "reasonable."

Pragmatic: Instead of wasting time wishing for a better reality, you are firmly rooted in your present situation. You prefer to find the most practical solution to a problem, even if it isn't always the most desirable.
Reckless: You believe that anyone who takes life too seriously will never know its true enjoyment. Meticulous plans and detailed outcome calculations are for others to worry about.
Serious: You have no time for self-indulgent nonsense. You understand your role and responsibilities in the universe and you wish that others understood theirs.

Flight Academy is tough, but you have a knack for it, and with a lot of practice in the simulator and just as much book learning, you complete your training. You pass your final flight test on a real shuttle and only have to pass the final written exam to become certified as a pilot.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Communal: You believe in community and cooperation. We can all succeed, if we work together. You organize a Study Group. Everyone will do much better working together, and you will benefit from their notes and thoughts.
Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

You are ready to be recruited to a crew and have but one question to answer: How will you expand your influence?

The endless void of space calls to you. You dream of one day taking the helm of an Adalian ship, and exploring the entirety of Adalia. 

You enroll in Flight Academy and on the first day of your training, you and all the other aspiring pilots log into the remote learning session hosted from Adalia Prime’s education center. 

The video feed shows an older woman with a pilot’s mask and the bald head favored by lifelong pilots - like mohawks and topknots, it keeps any hair away from the large radio headsets clasped over their ears while flying.

"Good morning, class," she begins once everyone is logged in and settled. "I’m Flight Instructor Murcheson, and I have the distinction of being one of the longest serving pilots in all of Adalia, since I was a Specialist running EVA flights over the outer hull of the Arvad, back when the old girl still flew."

A small whispered comment comes from someone’s live mic, but abruptly cuts off once whoever it is notices the microphone icon on their console.

"Yes, yes," Murcheson says, pausing briefly to address this. "That’s not the only distinction I have from back in the old days, I know. Anyone who is more interested in old court cases than flying should consider transferring to another program. I’m here to train pilots."

The session attendees are silent.

"Good," Murcheson continues. "Speaking of ancient history, back then we had almost no EVA techs, and none of them would even really pass as a pilot today. Once we knew we would be settling a whole asteroid belt, we started training shuttle pilots as quickly as we could, and even then it wasn’t enough to keep up with all the flights we needed, bringing a whole starship down to the surface in pieces." 

She frowns slightly.

"We still struggle to turn out enough pilots to keep our ever expanding fleets moving about in the belt. We are just about there now, where every crew that wants a pilot can get one.

"Pilots," she says, "will always be in high demand. You will always have a job to do and a destination to head toward…once you graduate."
paths.prompt: While you are learning the basics of flight there is one area which particularly interests you. Which specialty do you pursue?

linkedPaths.text: Navigator: You will have increased ship fuel efficency while travelling.
Buster: You will have increased top ship acceleration.
Operator: You will have reduced rate of wear during ship operation.

paths.content: Flight Academy is tough, but you have a knack for it, and with a lot of practice in the simulator and just as much book learning, you complete your training. You pass your final flight test on a real shuttle and only have to pass the final written exam to become certified as a pilot.
paths.prompt: This final exam is notoriously difficult and as it draws closer your classmates start to become anxious about it. In response to the mounting pressure, you are:

linkedPaths.text: Impartial: You are capable of viewing many issues without bias or prejudice. You will just take the Exam. You know the material; you aren’t that worried, actually. You’ll do fine.

Righteous: You believe that you are virtuous and hold others to a high moral standard. When no one is watching, you study. You have your notes and plenty of time to review them carefully. No shortcuts; no nonsense.

Enterprising: You are resourceful and able to build on the ideas of others. You sell a copy of your study notes. You feel pretty confident in the detailed notes you’ve been taking, but there are other students that have not been as diligent. You can help them out…for a price.

Opportunistic: You believe in taking advantage of being in the right place at the right time. You know how important this exam is, and you aren’t leaving anything to chance. When someone offers you a copy of the exam from another classmate taking it the day before your exam is scheduled, you gladly accept it.

paths.content: After managing to pass your final exam and graduate, you are now, officially, a Pilot of Adalia.
